curam.util.common.path
Interface PathResolver

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractClientResolver, curam.util.common.path.AbstractPathResolverPlugIn, DataAccessor
public interface PathResolver

An interface that describes the features of path resolvers that are responsible for locating the data identified by a path. Implementations of this interface may have different behavior under otherwise similar circumstances. This mostly relates to the handling of paths that cannot be resolved or that resolve to null values. The main distinction is whether the data source to which the path resolves contains a fixed set of available values or contains arbitrary or optional values.

To illustrate this, assume that there are a number of different data sources that all relate to simple "properties" files. These files contain simple key-value string pairs. Each path contains a single step that identifies the key and resolving the path to a value will get the value corresponding to the given key.

One properties file represents localized text for messages that will be reported to a user. It is appropriate that a path that defines a key that is not in this properties file should cause an exception when an attempt is made to resolve it. The implementation is justified in enforcing the need to have all of these messages available, as a missing message would be considered a defect that must be corrected. Therefore, a valid key always results in the message being returned, while an invalid key always results in an exception.

A second properties file represents a user's preferred color scheme for the display. The entries describe an element of the user interface and the color that should be used for that element, for example, "text=black". The display is customizable, so the the elements of the display are not limited to a predefined set. When a color for an element is not defined, a default color is assumed. In this case, it is appropriate that a path that represents a key that is not defined is resolved to null instead of causing an exception to be thrown. The system can interpret the null to mean "use the default color".

A third properties file represents the default color value used by the system. Here, the "default.color" key may be defined by the user to avoid having to change the color for each element of the user interface separately. The system will assume the default color is "blue" if none is defined in this properties file. In this case, it is appropriate that a path that represents this default color should resolve to the color value or to null if the property is not set. However, all other paths should trigger an exception, as there is no other valid keys that can be used, only the "default.color" key is understood by the system.

These three cases illustrate the reasons why different resolvers may have different behavior. The implementation-specific behavior will be documented where appropriate.

Method Detail

get

java.lang.String get(Path path)
                     throws DataAccessException
Gets the formatted string value of the data identified by the path. The data will be formatted with respect to the active locale and time zone. If the path represents a list, a list index must be applied or an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The formatted string value of the data (may be null).
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is invalid or a required value cannot be retrieved.

getGeneric

java.lang.String getGeneric(Path path)
                            throws DataAccessException
Gets the generically formatted string representation of the data identified by the path. The retrieved data will be independent from the user locale, so that the same path in any locale will always return the same generic data.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The generic value of the data (may be null).
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is invalid or a required value cannot be retrieved.

getList

java.util.List<java.lang.String> getList(Path path)
                                         throws DataAccessException

Gets a list of the formatted string values of the data identified by the path. The data will be formatted with respect to the active locale and time zone. If the path does not represent a list (or represents a single, indexed value from a list), an exception will be thrown.

If only the size of the list is of interest, use the PathResolver.count(Path) method instead, as it may be more efficient.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The list of formatted string values of the data. The list may be empty, but will never be null, though entries may be null. The list is not modifiable.
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is invalid or a required values cannot be retrieved.

getRaw

java.lang.Object getRaw(Path path)
                        throws DataAccessException
Gets the unformatted object representation of the data identified by the path. Other than the data type, this operates the same way as the PathResolver.get(Path) method.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The raw value of the data (may be null).
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is invalid or a required value cannot be retrieved.

getRawList

java.util.List<java.lang.Object> getRawList(Path path)
                                            throws DataAccessException
Gets a list of the unformatted object representations of the data identified by the path. Other than the data type, this operates the same way as the PathResolver.getList(Path) method.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The list of raw values of the data. The list may be empty, but will never be null. However, entries may be null. The list is not modifiable.
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is invalid or a required values cannot be retrieved.

Sets the formatted string value of the data identified by the path.

count

int count(Path path)
          throws DataAccessException

Gets the count of the values identified by the path. This may be more efficient than getting a list of values and then getting the size of the list if the list would not otherwise be used. The count will always be the same as the size of the list retrieved for the same path. Generally, where the PathResolver.getList(Path) method would throw an exception, this method will also throw an exception, for example, if the path does not resolve to a list.

When iterating over the elements in a list, do not use this method in the loop condition to control the number of iterations, as it may be very inefficient to call it repeatedly. Instead, get the list of values and get the size from the list using java.util.List.size() or use the list iterator.

Parameters:
path - The path to be resolved.
Returns:
The number of values identified by the path.
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the count cannot be calculated.

execute

void execute(Path path)
             throws DataAccessException
Executes the action described by the path. While most paths describe a reference to data, some describe an action that can be performed. For path resolvers that do not describe actions, an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
path - The path to be executed.
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the path is not executable, or if there is a problem during execution.

getSortOrder

int getSortOrder(Path path)
                 throws DataAccessException

Gets the sort order of a value identified by the path. If no sort order is defined for that value, -1 is returned.

Parameters:
path - The path to the value for which a sort order is to be returned.
Returns:
The sort order of the value. If no sort order is specified, -1 is returned.
Throws:
DataAccessException - If the data cannot be accessed.
